text: I first opened up my DMs- I had 'em closed, which is like traditionally the default on Twitter for a long time. 'Cause I was like, "Oh, if I open them up, I'll just get a bunch of spam and I don't need another inbox to- to call through." I opened it up quietly and, um, actually didn't get a lot of spam, uh, surprisingly.
speaker: Ryan Hoover
context: Lenny asks Ryan about his practice of offering free advice to founders who DM him on Twitter. Ryan explains how he initially hesitated to open his direct messages because he expected to receive spam, but was surprised to find that wasn't the case. This led to him actively inviting founders to reach out for advice, which he then sometimes shares publicly (anonymized) as a form of micro-blogging.
text_ko: 처음에 다이렉트 메시지(DMs)를 열었어요 — 원래 닫아놨었거든요. 트위터에서는 오랫동안 그게 기본 설정이었고요. '열어 놓으면 스팸(spam)이 막 올 거고, 또 하나 더 확인할 받은편지함은 필요 없을 거야'라고 생각했어요. 그래서 조용히 열어봤는데, 의외로 스팸이 많이 오지 않았어요.
text_zh: 我一开始把私信功能打开了——之前一直关着的，Twitter上默认设置就是关闭的嘛，用了很长时间都这样。因为我当时想，"哎呀，要是打开了，肯定会收到一大堆垃圾信息，我可不想再多一个收件箱要处理。" 结果我悄悄打开了，嗯，其实没收到什么垃圾信息，还挺意外的。
text_es: Primero abrí mis mensajes directos - los tenía cerrados, que es como tradicionalmente viene por defecto en Twitter desde hace mucho tiempo. Porque pensé, "Ay, si los abro, me van a llegar un montón de spam y no necesito otra bandeja de entrada que revisar." Los abrí sin hacer ruido y, eh, la verdad es que no me llegó tanto spam, sorprendentemente.

text: And maybe the biggest surprise was a lot of people are pretty vulnerable. These are strangers, founders who DM me saying, "Hey, I'm- we have three months runway left. We're running out of money. Here's a situation. What advice do you have?" Or just things that, you know, everyone has to wear this unfortunate mask is kind of the way I- what I used to describe it.
speaker: Ryan Hoover
context: Lenny asks what Ryan has learned from founders who DM him questions. Ryan explains that he was surprised by how vulnerable and authentic people are willing to be in private messages, sharing serious problems like running out of funding. He reflects on how founders typically have to project confidence publicly while dealing with significant challenges privately.
text_ko: 아마 제일 놀랐던 건 생각보다 많은 사람들이 꽤 취약하다는 점이에요. 모르는 사람들, 창업자들(founders)이 다이렉트 메시지(DM)로 “저희 런웨이(runway)가 3개월밖에 안 남았어요. 돈이 거의 다 떨어져가고 있어요. 이런 상황인데 조언해주실 수 있나요?”라고 보내요. 혹은 다들 어쩔 수 없이 불행한 가면을 써야 한다는 식의 얘기들인데, 제가 예전부터 그렇게 표현하곤 했던 방식이에요.
text_zh: 最让我意外的可能是，很多人其实挺脆弱的。这些素不相识的创始人会私信我说："嘿，我们——我们还有三个月的runway（资金跑道）就用完了，快没钱了。情况就是这样，你有什么建议吗？"或者聊一些别的事情，你知道的，每个人都得戴着这种让人无奈的面具，我以前是这么形容的。
text_es: Y tal vez la sorpresa más grande fue que mucha gente es bastante vulnerable. Son desconocidos, fundadores que me escriben por DM diciéndome: "Oye, nos quedan tres meses de runway, se nos está acabando el dinero. Esta es nuestra situación. ¿Qué consejo nos das?" O simplemente cosas que, ya sabes, todo mundo tiene que ponerse esta máscara desafortunada, así es como yo solía describirlo.

text: I do spend time, ironically, like. challenging founders sometimes when they're thinking about raising or thinking about an idea to- to not raise. Um, people who are in tech, uh, especially, are certain bubbles of tech, that's the default. It's like, "The first thing I do, I have an idea, now let's go raise money."
speaker: Ryan Hoover
context: Lenny asks Ryan about his advice to founders considering whether to start a company, given how difficult startups are. Ryan explains that he often challenges founders who assume they need to raise venture capital immediately after having an idea. He points out that in certain tech circles, fundraising has become the default first step, even when it may not be necessary or appropriate.
text_ko: 아이러니하게도 저는 창업자들(founders)이 자금 조달(raising)을 고민하거나 아예 안 하겠다고 생각할 때 그 생각에 대해 가끔 도전적으로 질문을 던지며 시간을 써요. 특히 테크(tech) 쪽 사람들은, 어떤 기술 버블(tech bubbles) 안에서는 그게 기본값이에요. '아이디어가 생기면 제일 먼저 투자 유치(raise money)를 하자'라는 식이죠.
text_zh: 我确实会花时间，挺讽刺的，就是有时候会质疑一些创始人，当他们在考虑融资或者在考虑某个想法的时候，我会建议他们别急着融资。搞科技的人，特别是在某些科技圈子里的人，融资已经成了默认选项了。就像"我一有想法，第一件事就是去融钱。"
text_es: Me paso tiempo, irónicamente, desafiando a los fundadores a veces cuando están pensando en levantar capital o considerando una idea para que... para que no levanten capital. La gente que está en tech, especialmente en ciertas burbujas del tech, eso es lo normal. Es como, "Lo primero que hago, tengo una idea, ahora vamos a buscar financiamiento."

text: I think it's super important that founders see a line of sight to work on this for ... I think my rule of thumb is a decade, just do you see yourself working on this for a decade? And maybe it's not a decade that you actually work on it. It probably won't, it either, it'll probably fail before then as most startups do, but I think it's a good litmus test for yourself.
speaker: Ryan Hoover
context: Ryan continues discussing his advice for founders considering starting a company. He explains his framework for evaluating startup commitment - founders should be able to envision working on their idea for a decade. While acknowledging that most startups fail before reaching that timeframe, he believes this long-term perspective serves as an important litmus test for genuine passion and commitment to the problem they're trying to solve.
text_ko: 창업자들이 이 일을 앞으로도 계속할 수 있다는 확신을 갖고 있는 게 정말 중요하다고 생각해요. 제 경험상 기준은 대략 10년이에요. 스스로 '내가 이걸 10년 동안 해도 괜찮을까?'라고 물어보는 거예요. 실제로 10년을 채 일하게 될지는 모르고, 대부분의 스타트업처럼 그 전에 실패할 가능성이 더 커요. 그래도 스스로를 평가해 보는 좋은 리트머스 테스트(litmus test)가 된다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得创始人得能看到自己会在这个项目上坚持下去，这点特别重要。我的经验法则就是十年，你能想象自己在这件事上干十年吗？当然不一定真的要干满十年，大概率也干不到，就像大部分创业公司一样，可能早就挂了。但我觉得这是个不错的试金石，可以测试一下自己。
text_es: Creo que es súper importante que los fundadores se vean trabajando en esto a largo plazo... Mi regla general es una década, ¿te ves trabajando en esto por diez años? Y tal vez no sean diez años los que realmente le dediques. Probablemente no sea así, lo más probable es que fracase antes como pasa con la mayoría de startups, pero creo que es una buena prueba de fuego para uno mismo.

text: I don't know how to articulate that- that feeling, but that flutter in your stomach that you wake up with in the morning of just anxiety and stress and- and worry. Um, being a CEO or founder makes it slightly harder, uh, in some ways, because you still have to put on this mask.
speaker: Ryan Hoover
context: Ryan is describing the emotional toll of being a founder during difficult periods at Product Hunt. He's explaining to Lenny the physical manifestation of startup stress - the stomach flutter of anxiety upon waking. He emphasizes how being in a leadership position compounds this difficulty because founders must project confidence externally while dealing with internal anxiety, creating additional pressure beyond the underlying business challenges.
text_ko: 그 느낌을 어떻게 말로 표현해야 할지 잘 모르겠어요 — 아침에 눈 뜰 때부터 가슴이 두근거리고 불안하고 스트레스와 걱정이 밀려오는 그런 느낌요. 최고경영자(CEO)나 창업자(founder)로서 보면 어떤 면에서는 그게 조금 더 힘들어요, 왜냐하면 여전히 겉으로는 괜찮은 척하는 가면을 써야 하거든요.
text_zh: 我不知道怎么形容那种感觉，就是早上醒来肚子里翻江倒海的那种焦虑、压力和担忧。当CEO或创始人会让这种感觉更难受，因为你还得装出一副若无其事的样子。
text_es: No sé cómo expresar esa... esa sensación, pero esas mariposas en el estómago con las que te despiertas por la mañana, pura ansiedad y estrés y... y preocupación. Eh, ser CEO o fundador lo hace un poco más difícil, eh, de cierta manera, porque aún tienes que ponerte esa máscara.

text: The biggest surprise has probably been ... There are cases when I didn't think the company would make it. I- uh, either the product wasn't working, and you know, many months had passed, and it was very clear that they're- they- well, to me, I thought it was clear that, okay, that this probably isn't gonna work out. In my head I kinda wrote it off.
speaker: Ryan Hoover
context: Lenny asks Ryan what has surprised him most about angel investing. Ryan explains that his biggest surprise has been seeing companies he had mentally written off as failures eventually succeed through pivots or unexpected breakthroughs. This taught him never to count portfolio companies out until they're definitively done, highlighting the unpredictable nature of startup journeys and the importance of backing resilient founders.
text_ko: 가장 놀랐던 건 아마도… 어떤 경우에는 제가 그 회사가 버티지 못할 거라고 생각했을 때예요. 저, 음, 제품이 제대로 작동하지 않거나 몇 달이 지나도 별 진전이 없어서 제게는 ‘아, 이건 안 될 것 같다’가 너무 분명해 보였어요. 그래서 속으로는 이미 접어뒀어요.
text_zh: 最大的意外可能就是...有些时候我觉得这家公司肯定要完蛋了。我...呃，要么就是产品根本搞不定，你知道的，好几个月过去了，我觉得很明显他们...他们...反正在我看来，就是很明显嘛，这事儿八成是黄了。我心里基本上已经把它给划掉了。
text_es: La sorpresa más grande probablemente ha sido... Hay casos en los que pensé que la empresa no lo iba a lograr. Yo... eh, o el producto no funcionaba, y sabes, habían pasado muchos meses, y para mí era muy claro que ellos... bueno, yo pensaba que era obvio que, okay, esto probablemente no va a salir adelante. En mi mente ya lo había dado por perdido.
